question_text: In the Heckscher-Ohlin model of international trade, what primary factor determines a country's pattern of comparative advantage and export specialization?
correct_answer: Its relative abundance of factors of production such as labor, capital, and land
distractors: Its level of technological innovation relative to trading partners
The absolute size of its gross domestic product
The geographic distance between it and its major trading partners

question_text: In econometrics, what two conditions must an instrumental variable satisfy to be considered valid for addressing endogeneity?
correct_answer: Relevance (correlated with the endogenous variable) and exogeneity (uncorrelated with the error term)
distractors: Normality (normally distributed) and homoscedasticity (constant variance)
Stationarity (constant mean over time) and ergodicity (time averages equal ensemble averages)
Sufficiency (captures all sample information) and completeness (identifies all parameters)

question_text: The Lorenz curve, developed by Max O. Lorenz in 1905, plots the cumulative share of income against the cumulative share of the population. What does the diagonal 45-degree line on this graph represent?
correct_answer: Perfect equality, where every percentile of the population earns the same share of income
distractors: The median income level across the entire population
The average tax rate applied to each income bracket
Perfect inequality, where one person holds all the income

question_text: The Stolper-Samuelson theorem (1941) predicts that a rise in the relative price of a good will have what effect on factor returns?
correct_answer: It raises the real return to the factor used most intensively in that good's production and lowers the return to the other factor
distractors: It raises real returns to all factors of production proportionally to the price increase
It lowers the real return to the factor used most intensively while raising returns to the scarce factor
It has no effect on factor returns because wages and rents adjust to maintain equilibrium

question_text: The Austrian School of economics, founded by Carl Menger in 1871, is distinguished by its strict adherence to which methodological principle?
correct_answer: Methodological individualism, holding that social phenomena arise from individual motivations and actions
distractors: Methodological holism, analyzing economies as irreducible aggregate systems
Logical positivism, requiring all economic claims to be empirically falsifiable
Historical materialism, grounding economic analysis in class relations and modes of production

question_text: The revealed comparative advantage (RCA) index, introduced by Béla Balassa in 1965, measures a country's export specialization. What does an RCA value greater than 1 indicate?
correct_answer: The country has a comparative advantage in that product, exporting more than its expected world share
distractors: The country imports more of that product than it exports
The country's production costs for that product exceed the world average
The country's tariff rate on that product is above the global median

question_text: Contingent valuation is a survey-based technique used in environmental economics. What does it primarily ask respondents to estimate?
correct_answer: Their willingness to pay for preserving or improving a non-market good such as biodiversity or clean air
distractors: The market price they would charge to sell a natural resource on the open market
The amount of tax revenue governments should allocate to environmental regulation
The replacement cost of damaged infrastructure after a natural disaster

question_text: The difference-in-differences (DiD) method estimates causal effects by comparing changes over time between a treatment group and a control group. What key assumption must hold for DiD estimates to be valid?
correct_answer: The parallel trends assumption: absent treatment, both groups would have followed the same trajectory over time
distractors: The independence assumption: treatment and control groups must be randomly assigned from the same population
The stationarity assumption: the outcome variable must have a constant mean and variance across all time periods
The homogeneity assumption: individuals within both groups must have identical observable characteristics

question_text: In the Arrow-Debreu model of general equilibrium, what mathematical tool was used to prove that a competitive equilibrium exists across all markets simultaneously?
correct_answer: The Kakutani fixed-point theorem, applied to a continuous mapping from a compact convex set into itself
distractors: The Lagrange multiplier method, optimizing utility subject to budget constraints
The central limit theorem, showing that aggregate demand converges to a normal distribution
The minimax theorem from game theory, ensuring optimal strategies in zero-sum markets

question_text: Arrow's impossibility theorem (1951) is a foundational result in social choice theory. What does the theorem prove about voting systems with three or more alternatives?
correct_answer: No ranked voting rule can simultaneously satisfy unrestricted domain, Pareto efficiency, independence of irrelevant alternatives, and non-dictatorship
distractors: All majority-rule systems inevitably produce Pareto-optimal outcomes when voters are fully informed
Any ranked voting rule will always select the Condorcet winner if one exists among the alternatives
A unique social welfare function exists that maximizes aggregate utility across all possible preference orderings
